metadata.sermon_title: A Word To Young Preachers On The Name Of The Savior
metadata.sermon_start_end: Our Father and our God, we thank thee for the bright beauty of early morning and for the swift and awful gift of life, for its opportunities and obligations, for its light moments and for its solemn times. We thank thee for every gift which gives grace [...] I think only then will we begin to see the glory of the Lord whose we are, the winsome wonder of our Lord, Jesus Christ.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: While John 1 is read, the sermon does not treat it as a specific pericope. Instead, it uses the text as a springboard for a general discourse on the names 'Jesus' and 'Christ'. It fails to identify what is unique to John 1 that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: Let us ponder the name of the Savior.
I recognize that in taking the name of the Savior, Jesus Christ, we have a subject far beyond the power of any creature...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific Johannine logic of the 'Logos' becoming flesh rather than a general thematic study of the names of Jesus.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exegesis of the Greek text or the historical context of the Johannine community. The preacher relies on secondary anecdotes (Spurgeon, Buttrick, Maclaren) rather than primary exposition of the biblical text's original meaning.
quotes: Alexander Maclaren has pointed out, for instance...
When James Denny did his monumental work in 1908...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the original meaning of 'Logos' in its Jewish and Hellenistic context to ground the sermon in scholarly exposition as Dekker requires.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application touches on social issues (racism, poverty in India), but remains somewhat anecdotal and illustrative rather than a direct application of the specific text to the immediate congregation's spiritual life.
quotes: The problems of New York. The problems of wherever!
It was the evil of racism in his own people which first alienated Jesus...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'the problems of wherever' to the specific spiritual and ethical situation of the hearers in the room.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured more as a lecture or a 'word of encouragement' than an interwoven movement of text and hearer. The text is read in a block and then used as a thematic anchor for various reflections.
quotes: Let me read these words from the first chapter of the Gospel according to John...
So we take that word Jesus...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'reading then talking' structure; allow the text's own movement to dictate the application throughout the sermon.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon acknowledges unworthiness (misery) and the gift of Christ (redemption), but the 'misery' aspect is somewhat softened by a focus on 'high adventure' and 'vision'.
quotes: We recognize that we are not worthy to be called thy children...
recognizing that we are saved by thy grace and thy mercy.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by addressing the 'gone wrongness' not just as a social structure but as a personal reality before God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways'—the possibility of being lost—is almost entirely absent. The tone is overwhelmingly optimistic and inclusive, lacking the 'ultimate possibilities' Dekker demands.
quotes: Jesus is the Lord. He will not leave us. Though our fathers and our mothers leave, he will not leave us.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the gravity of John 1:11 ('his own received him not') as a real possibility for the current hearer.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher explicitly affirms the two-natures doctrine and the necessity of Christ's divinity for salvation.
quotes: He is Divinity! Now, there is no Christian faith without that.
He is not only the Son of God; he is God the Son.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that this Christology is derived directly from the specific mechanics of the text rather than systematic theology alone.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The sermon meets the length requirement (approx. 21 minutes) and attempts a degree of breadth by referencing various theologians and global contexts.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Shift the 'breadth' from anecdotal illustrations to deeper exegetical layers.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily in its lack of specific exegetical grounding and the absence of the 'two ways'. It functions more as a thematic address on Christology than an exposition of John 1. While it is strongly Christocentric and meets the length requirement, it relies too heavily on anecdotes and general truths rather than the 'unique point' of the specific passage.
strengths: Strong commitment to the divinity of Christ (Thesis 7).
Adequate length to allow for thematic development (Thesis 8).
Clear attempt to link faith to concrete human reality (Thesis 3).
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis of the Greek text or original context (Thesis 2).
Failure to address the possibility of being lost or the seriousness of choice (Thesis 6).
Thematic approach overrides the specificities of the Bible passage (Thesis 1).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate theological speech, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It lacks the rigorous exposition of a specific pericope and the necessary tension of the 'two ways'.
